head.title: Palestinian Expulsions Won't Stop Peace Talks; Safety of Citizens First

hedline.hl1: Palestinian Expulsions Won't Stop Peace Talks; Safety of Citizens First

block.p: In "Don't Orphan the Peace Process" (editorial, Dec. 18), you shamefully suggest that Israel's attempt to insure the safety of its population and the brutality of Hamas have equal negative impacts on the peace talks.

In "Don't Orphan the Peace Process" (editorial, Dec. 18), you shamefully suggest that Israel's attempt to insure the safety of its population and the brutality of Hamas have equal negative impacts on the peace talks.

Since assuming leadership, the Rabin Government has unambiguously demonstrated its commitment to the peace process. From relaxing restrictions in the territories to being more flexible on the participation of certain Palestinians and others in the talks, Israel is the last party that has to prove its desire for peace. Nor is it morally acceptable for Israel to be held hostage to the peace process and sacrifice safety and security.

If anything, Israel's action was an effort to save, not derail, the peace process. Israelis from all sides of the political spectrum will not support a process that threatens their safety. Removing those responsible for the wave of terror is the only way the peace process can survive and thrive.

The undeniable importance of the peace process must not obstruct our abilities to distinguish between the actions of a government that seeks first to preserve human life and a terrorist faction that seeks to destroy it. ABRAHAM H. FOXMAN National Director, Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith New York, Dec. 18, 1992
